image.altText: Bald man in dark blue suit walking

items.synopsis: Charlie Teo was fighting two complaints of unprofessional conduct from the families of two different women, who say they were not properly warned about the risk of death before consenting to surgery.

title.children: Neurosurgeon Charlie Teo found guilty of unsatisfactory professional conduct

image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe announces big changes to RBA board, including fewer board meetings a year, and press conferences after every meeting.

title.children: Reserve Bank board to only meet eight times as year as part of big changes, says governor Philip Lowe

image.altText: An image of the Reserve bank sign in Martin Place, Sydney

items.synopsis: RBA governor Philip Lowe is speaking in Brisbane where he's expected to discuss changes to the bank's structure and reasons for pausing its current rate hiking cycle last week. Follow live.

title.children: RBA governor reveals changes to bank's structure and reasons for rate pause

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: (These questioners aren't giving their names before speaking, so apologies for not including them.) This questioner asked: "Canada, UK, New  Zealand and USA have all started  their monetary targeting earlier  than Australia. Can you speak on the decisions thus far to be less  aggressive than our partners in our cash rate hikes, and given Australia inflation is higher than most of  these countries, is it potential for not us further but more aggressive targeting as well?" Here's Lowe's reply: "Most of the  central banks have higher interest rates than we have, so it is a good question about why we haven't raised rates even further. "There are a  number of factors. The first is that normal wages growth in Australia is still lower than it is in most other advanced economies. The aggregate  level, wages are growing between 3.5 and 4%. "In the US, Canada, the UK  and about 5%, in some cases above  6%. It is quite a difference. "A  second, and this is related, that  supply in Australia is a lot more  flexible than other countries, our participation rate here is setting record highs every month. So the  domestic population, more and more have entered the labour force and  the supply side of labour is much  more flexible than in the US where the participation rate still hasn't got back to its previous peak. "So  they are two reasons why the  underlying inflation pressures in  Australia are less than they are in some countries, and it is really  important that that remains the  case. "If we saw Australia in the  same situation as in the US, Canada, UK, where wages were growing at 6%, that would have implications for our setting of monetary policy. The  other element is we have been  prepared to allow inflation to come back to target a bit more slowly and some other central banks." Lowe says the RBA is trying to preserve the labour market: "We have been prepared to go a bit  slower to try and preserve those  gains in the labour market that we have got over the last two years. "It took us nearly 50 years to get back to full employment. We are probably through that, but youth unemployment is the lowest it has been in  decades, people have been able to  get jobs, so there is a huge  economic and social benefit. "So we took the decision to go a bit more slowly back to the target than some other central banks to try and  preserve that, and I still hope we can manage it."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Could we see more aggressive cash rate hikes like we have overseas?

children.content: (These questioners aren't giving their names before speaking, so apologies for not including them.)
This questioner asked:

"Canada, UK, New  Zealand and USA have all started  their monetary targeting earlier  than Australia. Can you speak on the decisions thus far to be less  aggressive than our partners in our cash rate hikes, and given Australia inflation is higher than most of  these countries, is it potential for not us further but more aggressive targeting as well?"
Here's Lowe's reply:
"Most of the  central banks have higher interest rates than we have, so it is a good question about why we haven't raised rates even further.

"There are a  number of factors. The first is that normal wages growth in Australia is still lower than it is in most other advanced economies. The aggregate  level, wages are growing between 3.5 and 4%.
"In the US, Canada, the UK  and about 5%, in some cases above  6%. It is quite a difference.

"A  second, and this is related, that  supply in Australia is a lot more  flexible than other countries, our participation rate here is setting record highs every month. So the  domestic population, more and more have entered the labour force and  the supply side of labour is much  more flexible than in the US where the participation rate still hasn't got back to its previous peak.
"So  they are two reasons why the  underlying inflation pressures in  Australia are less than they are in some countries, and it is really  important that that remains the  case.

"If we saw Australia in the  same situation as in the US, Canada, UK, where wages were growing at 6%, that would have implications for our setting of monetary policy. The  other element is we have been  prepared to allow inflation to come back to target a bit more slowly and some other central banks."
Lowe says the RBA is trying to preserve the labour market:
"We have been prepared to go a bit  slower to try and preserve those  gains in the labour market that we have got over the last two years.

"It took us nearly 50 years to get back to full employment. We are probably through that, but youth unemployment is the lowest it has been in  decades, people have been able to  get jobs, so there is a huge  economic and social benefit.
"So we took the decision to go a bit more slowly back to the target than some other central banks to try and  preserve that, and I still hope we can manage it."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The questioner asked Lowe if inflation was largely driven by "greedy corporations", as is the thinking out of the Australian Institute. Here's what he said in response: "The aggregate data show that the profits share  excluding the resources sector,  which is appropriate to treat them differently, the share has not  risen in Australia. "What we have  seen is firms be able to increase  their prices in line with the higher input costs. Being able to pass on input costs fully and preserve the proper margins, but the profit  margins have not blown out. "There  are some specific firms where you  could say the profits have  increased, but by and large, they  are confined to specific areas of  the economy, and across the economy as a whole, profit margins have not risen. So it is not a source of  inflation. "It is contributed in some cases but it is not the primary  source of inflation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is inflation being driven higher by 'greedy corporations'?

children.content: The questioner asked Lowe if inflation was largely driven by "greedy corporations", as is the thinking out of the Australian Institute.
Here's what he said in response:
"The aggregate data show that the profits share  excluding the resources sector,  which is appropriate to treat them differently, the share has not  risen in Australia.

"What we have  seen is firms be able to increase  their prices in line with the higher input costs. Being able to pass on input costs fully and preserve the proper margins, but the profit  margins have not blown out.

"There  are some specific firms where you  could say the profits have  increased, but by and large, they  are confined to specific areas of  the economy, and across the economy as a whole, profit margins have not risen. So it is not a source of  inflation.
"It is contributed in some cases but it is not the primary  source of inflation."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This question is being asked on behalf of Brisbane Girls Grammar, who won a competition to ask Philip Lowe a question. Here's what they asked him: Since 2022, most advanced economies have been  hiking interest rates in a similar pattern to fight inflation. Interest rate changes in foreign economies  such as the US have an important  impact on our inflation and exchange rates, so we wonder, how much of an  impact of decisions made by other  central banks have Australian  monetary policy? Here's Lowe's answer: "All the central banks are raising rates, at least  most of them, for the same reason. Inflation is too high. "First of all, because of COVID supply disruptions and because of brush's invasion of Ukraine and then, more recently,  because of strong growth in unit  labour costs, stronger as in wages, productivity and that is keeping  services price inflation. That is a common story across most of the  advanced economies, and that is why we are all raising rates. We are not raising rates here because the US is raising them. But we are raising  them because we are facing the same general economic situation as the  United States. So that is how it  works. There is a potential link  through what other central banks do through the exchange rates. If the US was to raise rates and we didn't, then the US dollar tends to  strengthen the Australian dollar  would appreciate and that would  bring Australia inflation. That  could influence our decisions. But it is very much at the margin. "We  are raising rates because we need  to, because of our particular  circumstances, not because the US is."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'We are raising rates because we need to ... not because the US is'

children.content: This question is being asked on behalf of Brisbane Girls Grammar, who won a competition to ask Philip Lowe a question.
Here's what they asked him:

Since 2022, most advanced economies have been  hiking interest rates in a similar pattern to fight inflation. Interest rate changes in foreign economies  such as the US have an important  impact on our inflation and exchange rates, so we wonder, how much of an  impact of decisions made by other  central banks have Australian  monetary policy?
Here's Lowe's answer:
"All the central banks are raising rates, at least  most of them, for the same reason. Inflation is too high.

"First of all, because of COVID supply disruptions and because of brush's invasion of Ukraine and then, more recently,  because of strong growth in unit  labour costs, stronger as in wages, productivity and that is keeping  services price inflation.
That is a common story across most of the  advanced economies, and that is why we are all raising rates.
We are not raising rates here because the US is raising them. But we are raising  them because we are facing the same general economic situation as the  United States. So that is how it  works.
There is a potential link  through what other central banks do through the exchange rates.

If the US was to raise rates and we didn't, then the US dollar tends to  strengthen the Australian dollar  would appreciate and that would  bring Australia inflation. That  could influence our decisions. But it is very much at the margin.
"We  are raising rates because we need  to, because of our particular  circumstances, not because the US is."

image.altText: shot of lake from above

items.synopsis: A small lake near the Canada-US border has been chosen as the site that may define the start of a new geological epoch called the Anthropocene.

title.children: A 'golden spike' in Canada could mark the beginning of the Anthropocene Epoch

image.altText: Bryan Brown smiles against a blue background.

items.synopsis: Australian actor Bryan Brown is addressing the National Press Club in Canberra - follow live.

title.children: Actor Bryan Brown calls for streaming revenues to be reinvested in Australian movies and TV

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Brown has been asked his thoughts on the referendum later this year. "I will be voting yes," he says. "If Marcia Langton says it is the right thing to do, then I will do it. "Simple as that."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brown asked about Voice referendum

children.content: Brown has been asked his thoughts on the referendum later this year.
"I will be voting yes," he says.
"If Marcia Langton says it is the right thing to do, then I will do it.
"Simple as that."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Brown says it would not make any sense for them to pull out of Australia. "They want to make money and if there is a lot of money to be made in Australia," he says. "We love watching the shows we love and turning on the streamers." However, he says Australia needs to step up and say "step up to the mark" and make local content.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will streaming services withdraw if there is a content quota in Australia?

children.content: Brown says it would not make any sense for them to pull out of Australia.
"They want to make money and if there is a lot of money to be made in Australia," he says.
"We love watching the shows we love and turning on the streamers."
However, he says Australia needs to step up and say
"step up to the mark" and make local content.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Brown says about $2 billion is handed to the steamers by consumers and they receive an offset that allows them to film their shows. He says a percentage of the $2 billion should go back into producing Australian stories. "We have got to be able to hold our heads up," he says. "That extra money allows us more time to develop and shoot and to allow us to make our shows reach the great heights we want them to." He says it is about 1 per cent of the global revenue the streaming giants make, but "it is a lot of money to us".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brown says it's important Australian stories don't get lost amid streaming

children.content: Brown says about $2 billion is handed to the steamers by consumers and they receive an offset that allows them to film their shows.
He says a percentage of the $2 billion should go back into producing Australian stories.
"We have got to be able to hold our heads up," he says.
"That extra money allows us more time to develop and shoot and to allow us to make our shows reach the great heights we want them to."
He says it is about 1 per cent of the global revenue the streaming giants make, but "it is a lot of money to us".

image.altText: A man with bandages on his arms talks to a blonde woman

items.synopsis: Witnesses have begun giving evidence in the Whakaari White Island trial in New Zealand with one survivor telling the court he would not have been on the volcano if he understood how active it was at the time.

title.children: 'She just said run': Whakaari White Island survivor gives evidence on 'chaotic' evacuation

image.altText: Erica Vlasic in her living room.

items.synopsis: Erika Vlasic received two reports about a home she wanted to buy. She said one came back with "no big issues", the other found the property was suited to "demolition".

title.children: When Erika offered $700k for a home, she didn't know it was 'better suited to demolition'

image.altText: Blue and white police tape in front of traffic accident scene

items.synopsis: Police allege a driver deliberately went around boom gates, just moments before it was struck by a fully loaded coal train.

title.children: Fatal coal train crash ends horror day on north Queensland roads

image.altText: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, center, arrives for an event on the sidelines of a NATO summit.

image.altText: Australia's first weatherman Alan Wilkie reads the weather in 1976 on 7 News

title.children: 'The most unlikely TV star': Australia's first on-screen weatherman, Alan Wilkie, dies aged 94

image.altText: A man wearing glasses and a black hoodie

title.children: Prosecution given access to medical and employment records of driver charged over deadly Hunter bus crash

image.altText: An illustration of two women, one with her hand on the other's shoulder, in front of a stained glass window.

title.children: How Christianity has been weaponised by weight loss movements

image.altText: The side of a white whale in water

items.synopsis: Researcher John Totterdell says he has never seen a "100 per cent" all-white humpback whale like the calf spotted by several groups at Ningaloo Reef off WA's north-west coast on Tuesday.

title.children: Is this Ningaloo's Migaloo? White humpback whale calf sighted in Western Australia

image.altText: Police commissioner Katarina Carroll addresses the media while dressed in uniform

items.synopsis: About 15,000 people from overseas have expressed interest in joining the Queensland police following its global recruitment drive.

title.children: 'Singapore, Fiji, South Africa': Queensland police get 'extraordinary response' from overseas recruitment drive

image.altText: A young white woman with glasses sits at a desk in front of a laptop.

items.synopsis: Australians targeted by the illegal robodebt income averaging scheme are considering their legal options after the damning royal commission report suggested there was evidence to support a further civil case.

title.children: Robodebt report provides avenue for further civil action and compensation for victims

image.altText: Woman wearing headphones working on laptop computer

items.synopsis: Is it OK to wear headphones in the office? Do they help get work done, or is wearing them considered rude and damaging to the office vibe?

title.children: Workers hate office noise – but is using headphones to shut out colleagues the solution?

image.altText: A young bespectacled man with dark, curly hair and a beard.

items.synopsis: Owen Townsend, 25, went missing last Friday. Police suspect he may have become stuck in a swamp.

title.children: Gippsland resident chances across young man missing for five days, drives him to grandma's house

image.altText: Stuart Dew looks downwards

items.synopsis: A week after receiving a vote of confidence from the Gold Coast board, Stuart Dew has been sacked as the Suns' head coach. Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson look at what went wrong, and why the future might be still be bright for the Suns.

title.children: Why Stuart Dew was sacked — but the future is still bright for the Suns

image.altText: Professor Leonie Barner

items.synopsis: Scientists have developed an adhesive putty that can glue broken pieces of coral back together, which "has no harmful effects on the marine environment".

title.children: These scientists have a novel way of solving the Great Barrier Reef's coral rubble problem: glue

image.altText: An elderly Indigenous man looks at the camera

items.synopsis: Ned Hargraves says many in his remote desert community still do not understand what they will be voting for, and is calling for the Voice referendum to be postponed so people have to chance to understand it.

title.children: Warlpiri elder will be voting against the Voice in the upcoming referendum. Here's why

image.altText: Elina Svitolina crouches down and covers her mouth on Wimbledon's Centre Court

items.synopsis: Elina Svitolina tells the world she will celebrate one of the biggest wins of her career with a beer as she returns to the semis of Wimbledon eight months after giving birth.

title.children: Tennis's comeback queen stuns world number one Iga Swiatek to be one match from Wimbledon final

image.altText: ce patterns settle on a car roof in Donnybrook, Western Australia

items.synopsis: If you live in a frost-prone region you are likely familiar with the mosaic-like branches and spirals that stretch across windows and cars on an ice-cold morning. But how does Mother Nature create the magnificent display?

title.children: This isn't art. It's ice, sculpted by Mother Nature

image.altText: Man wearing navy uniform

items.synopsis: The Russian military official was shot dead by an unknown assassin while on his morning run after appearing on a Ukrainian blacklist website.

title.children: 'Liquidated': Russian commander on Ukraine's blacklist shot dead on run

image.altText: A harvester cuts through cane field while a tractor loaded with a hauling bin drives alongside to collect the harvested cane.

items.synopsis: A free trade deal between Australia and the EU is at a standstill after the trade minister walks away from negotiations in Brussels without an agreement.

title.children: Australia and European Union at an impasse over free trade deal despite visit to break deadlock

image.altText: Aretha Franklin sings into a microphone

items.synopsis: The decision marks a critical turn in a dispute that has seen her sons locked in a legal battle over the will since her death in 2018.

title.children: Document found in Aretha Franklin's couch is a valid will, jury says

image.altText: Rows of empty seats as thousands of spotlights glimmer overhead. A spotlight shines a circle on the stage below.

items.synopsis: From building sets to on-stage mishaps, there's a certain drama involved in the making of theatre. Soon, it will be revealed to all.

title.children: Peek behind the curtain at Queensland Theatre as Brisbane Open House reveals how the 'magic' happens

image.altText: A woman wearing a labcoat and hair net holds a white plate of steaks.

items.synopsis: Researchers make big strides in plans to reduce the effect of cattle burps and farts on climate change by feeding the animals asparagopsis oil.

title.children: High-end steaks still tasty when cattle eat seaweed to tackle climate change

image.altText: Croc hunting

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory chief minister has reignited the crocodile culling debate following an attack at a popular swimming spot. A professor calls her reaction "knee-jerk".

title.children: Should crocodiles be culled again in the NT? Here's what happened last time

image.altText: Ava the dog is standing attentively on a rug and sniffing Donna's head, while Donna hugs Ava and laughs.

items.synopsis: For two decades, Donna has travelled confidently around the world and through Sydney with the support of various guide dogs. So what happens when one suddenly passes away?

title.children: 'I felt my safety was out of my control': Donna's world was turned upside down when her beloved guide dog died
